TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit Oid extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Represents a cryptographic object identifier. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Cryptographic object identifiers consist of a value/name pair. If one property in a pair is set to a known value, the other property is updated automatically to a corresponding value. For example, if the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid.Value%2A> property is set to "1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.4", the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid.FriendlyName%2A> property, which is localized, is set automatically to "Secure Email".
## Examples The following code example shows how to use the Oid class.
[!code-cs[Cryptography.Oid#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.security.crypto_42_1.cs)] [!code-vb[Cryptography.Oid#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.security.crypto_42_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[Cryptography.Oid#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/t-system.security.crypto_42_1.cpp)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(string value, string friendlyName) cil managed

Docs.param: The dotted number of the identifier.
The friendly name of the identifier.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified value and friendly name.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This constructor can be used to copy the values of an existing <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid> object. Note that if the Oid value is not recognized, the `value` and `friendlyName` parameters are not verified to determine if they correspond to each other. This is because there are object identifiers that the .NET Framework does not recognize, although an application may be able to interpret them.
## Examples The following code example shows how to use the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid> class.
[!code-cs[Cryptography.Oid#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.security.crypto_97_1.cs)] [!code-vb[Cryptography.Oid#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.security.crypto_97_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[Cryptography.Oid#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.security.crypto_97_1.cpp)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the friendly name of the identifier.
Docs.value: The friendly name of the identifier.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If one value of an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid> property is set to a known value, the other value of an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid> property is updated automatically to a corresponding value. For example, if the FriendlyName property is set to "Secure Email", the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid.Value%2A> property is set automatically to "1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.4".
## Examples The following code example shows how to use the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid> class.
[!code-cs[Cryptography.Oid#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.security.crypto_11_1.cs)] [!code-vb[Cryptography.Oid#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.security.crypto_11_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[Cryptography.Oid#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.security.crypto_11_1.cpp)]

Docs.returns: A new instance of an object.
Docs.exception: The friendly name for the OID value was not found.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the dotted number of the identifier.
Docs.value: The dotted number of the identifier.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If one value of an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid> property is set to a known value, the other value of an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid> property is updated automatically to a corresponding value. For example, if the Value property is set to "1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.4", the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid.FriendlyName%2A> property is set automatically to "Secure Email".
